stem: A 5-week-old infant is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of projectile, non-bilious vomiting. The infant is lethargic with sunken fontanelles. An olive-shaped mass is palpated in the right upper quadrant (RUQ). Complete the bowtie to guide care.

actions.text: Maintain NPO status and initiate intravenous (IV) fluids (D5NS with 20 mEq/L KCl).
Prepare the infant for surgical pyloromyotomy.
Apply a warm compress to the RUQ mass.

parameters.text: Auscultate and document bowel sound frequency and characteristics.
Monitor intake and output (I&O) and daily weight.

rationale.correct: The clinical presentation of projectile, non-bilious vomiting, lethargy, sunken fontanelles, and a palpable olive-shaped mass in the RUQ strongly suggests hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The priority is to correct dehydration and electrolyte imbalances (hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis) with IV fluids and prepare the infant for surgical pyloromyotomy. Monitoring fluid and electrolyte balance, as well as I&O and daily weight, is crucial for assessing the effectiveness of interventions.
rationale.incorrect: Initiating feedings would exacerbate the vomiting and increase the risk of aspiration. Applying a warm compress to the RUQ mass is not indicated and would not address the underlying problem. While assessing bowel sounds and abdominal circumference are part of a general abdominal assessment, they are not the primary indicators for monitoring the infant's stabilization and response to treatment in this specific condition.
clinicalPearls: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis typically presents between 2 and 8 weeks of age.
Non-bilious vomiting indicates an obstruction proximal to the duodenum.

questionTrap.trap: Focusing solely on the palpable mass and overlooking the systemic effects of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Recognize that the palpable mass is a key diagnostic finding, but addressing the dehydration and electrolyte imbalances is the immediate priority.

mnemonic.title: Pyloric Stenosis Management

reviewUnits.heading: Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis: Pathophysiology and Clinical Presentation
reviewUnits.body: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is characterized by hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction. Classic symptoms include projectile, non-bilious vomiting, dehydration, and a palpable olive-shaped mass in the RUQ. Electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, are common.

reviewUnits.heading: Priority Nursing Interventions for Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis
reviewUnits.body: The priority nursing interventions include maintaining NPO status, initiating IV fluids (D5NS with KCl) to correct dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, and preparing the infant for surgical pyloromyotomy. Monitoring serum electrolytes, I&O, and daily weight are essential for assessing the effectiveness of treatment.

reviewUnits.heading: Differentiating Bilious and Non-Bilious Vomiting
reviewUnits.body: Non-bilious vomiting suggests an obstruction proximal to the duodenum, such as pyloric stenosis. Bilious vomiting indicates an obstruction distal to the duodenum.
